status_message:
Community Update on Frank Larkings Boat

Following the KaipéÅtiki Local Board Meeting of 19/04/2017 and resolution CP2017/06008 the project to renew the play boat/pontoon at Hilders Park, more commonly known as "Frank Larking's Boat", has been handed to the Community Facilities Investigation and Design Team (I&D).

As the community has also raised concerns in regards to the furniture renewal at Hilders Reserve, in particularly with regards to the memorial seating, the project to renew the furniture has also been handed to I&D.

The I&D team plan to progress the boat and furniture projects jointly through the Investigation and design phase of the project. The I&D team plan to undertake the following next steps to progress these renewal projects:

1. Undertake further investigations to clarify the immediate health and safety obligations of Auckland Council in order to keep the existing boat in this location.
    * The boat is currently still open to public access.
    * I&D understand that the Board are to be kept informed 
       should the current situation change.

2. Undertake further investigations to clarify the ongoing health and safety obligations of Auckland Council if a play boat was kept in this location in some form (either through repair of existing, or a replica).

3. Gain good understanding of the community expectations and desired outcomes in regards to Hilders Park and Larking's Landing assets, in particular the memorial seats and the play boat.
      * This has already begun by I&D staff meeting with community representatives Ruth Jackson and Cindy Starnes on site and through reviewing the feedback on these projects to date.

4. Investigate further any heritage values associated with the boat and memorial seats.

5. Investigate options to retain the memorial seats in some form.

6. Investigate further the options to retain a play boat at Hilders Park, either through repair of the existing or a replica boat.
     * This will include the capital and operational costs associated with keeping a play boat in this location.
     * Costs will be sought from a qualified boat builder and will include ensuring the health and safety obligations for council 

Once the above steps have been undertaken, I&D will report back to the board at a workshop with the above information.

Due to the work required to undertake the above steps I&D do not anticipate being in a position to report back to the board until after July 2017.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
We want your feedback on Easter Sunday trading in Auckland

Auckland Council wants to know what people that live and work in the Auckland region think about changing shop trading rules to allow more businesses to open on Easter Sunday. 

A recent law change means Auckland Council can decide whether to allow more shops to open on Easter Sunday. 

The council's Governing Body has decided to ask Aucklanders whether they want the council to leave things as they are or create a policy to allow more shops to open. 

Currently, only some shops, like service stations, dairies, pharmacies and food outlets, are allowed to open on Easter Sunday. Supermarkets and general retailers must remain closed. 

Visit shapeauckland.co.nz to have your say. Feedback closes at 4pm on Sunday 11 June.

http://shapeauckland.co.nz/consultations/easter-sunday-trading-tell-us-what-you-think/
link_name: About

status_message: A plea from the local pony club  É?? if you love seeing the horses grazing on Kepa Rd and want to keep some green space for urban kids to learn to ride, please read this and give feedback today on the removal of the St Heliers Bay Pony Clubfrom the fields on Kepa Rd. The land is co-managed by Auckland Council and NgéÅti WhéÅtua è?réÅkei, and Council's given the Club notice to leave the land in July. The community club is one of the last places city kids can ride and learn to care for their horses, not to mention the great programs, such as Riding for the Disabled, which run from there as well. As one member points out too, Council hasn't revealed any plans for the land, and grazing horses do an excellent job at keeping down the grass, privet and gorse. You can submit on this today as part of Local Board plan feedback É?? you don't need to be an Orakei Local Board resident to do so. See www.shapeauckland.co.nz for the Draft Local Board plan feedback forms. Local author Stacy Gregg (pictured) grazes her horse at Kepa Rd, and says it's "the nicest, most down-to-earth club full of kids who love their ponies".
link_name: Shape Auckland

With winter officially here it's a timely reminder to make sure your rental home is warm and as dry as we head in to winter.   

If you own a rental property in the Puketapapa Local Board area, you could be eligible for a free independent, confidential healthy rentals assessment for your property and subsidies of 20 per cent or more on some improvements such as insulation, ground sheets, heat pumps and extractor fans if you get in before the end of June.    

Don't get left out in the cold, go to the council's website to see if you are eligible for the Healthy Rentals programme.

status_message:
Interested in saving energy, waste reduction, sustainability, transport or the natural environment, and how these things might contribute to a lower carbon footprint in your community or for your business?

The PuketéÅpapa Local Board is supporting a free one-day climathon to collaborate, find solutions and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

This climathon will provide an opportunity to scale up existing actions, find new collaborators, or start something completely new!

Please join us and bring your energy, enthusiasm, ideas, success stories, knowledge and experience.

We need:
É?Ω	Idea generators: new idea or initiative generators
É?Ω	Hackers: technical know-how in areas such as transport, waste, energy, natural environment, industry, community engagement
É?Ω	Hustlers: those who will make it happen, develop the business case, build the team, find the funds
É?Ω	Doers: put the plan in action, see it through

Lunch will be provided.

Spaces are limited, so please RSVP to lowcarbonliving@aucklandcouncil.govt.nz by 10am Monday 15 May.
For more information contact: Rebecca.Hayden@aucklandcouncil.govt.nz
link_name: PuketéÅpapa Local Board area climathon

status_message:
CALLING ALL HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO WANT TO MAKE A CHANGE AND GET INVOLVED WITH SOCIAL ENTERPRISE!

Social Innovation New Zealand is running the AdviSE Case Competition in a couple of weeks! This competition gives students an opportunity to compete in teams and learn more about social enterprises in the Auckland community. Teams are challenged to prepare and deliver a 10 minute presentation that identifies the key issues faced by the social enterprise and come up with potential  solutions.

This is an awesome opportunity to develop your knowledge of social enterprise while honing your case consulting, public speaking, and critical thinking skills in a very short time! Make sure to check out the event page below for more details!
link_name: AdviSE: Social Enterprise Competition for High Schools

status_message: Work gets underway soon on a new pathway linking the residential suburbs of Pakuranga and Burswood and the industrial/business area of Highbrook.  Local board members recently turned the sod to kick off the project.   Great for recreational use, the new path will also provide an alternative pedestrian and cycling route - away from busy roads.  Work is expected to be finished in October this year.

status_message:
We're developing our Local Board Plan 2017 and want to know what you think about some of the projects and outcomes we propose focusing on over the next three years.
These include continued investment in upgrading sportsfields and community facilities, improving public transport and investigating a local targeted rate to allow free access to our swimming pools.
It's easy to get involved and have your say.
Come on down to the Botany Night Markets - and meet our Local Board members and staff - have a chat and give your feedback on the draft plan.
Just go online to shapeauckland.co.nz to read the draft
Howick Local Board Plan and to make a submission.
Feedback accepted from 22 May to 30 June.

status_message:
BIG IMPROVEMENTS to bus services are launching on 11 June for the Norwest. A totally revamped new bus network is starting up to give Huapai, Kumeu, Waimauku and Helensville more services (including a Sunday service), more frequent services (including 6 morning and 6 evening Express buses), more direct services (buses will not go via Henderson but straight to the city cutting off 1/2 an hour traveling time), 2 hourly services from Helensville during the day, hourly services from Huapai. MORE SERVICES will be added over the coming years - including Park 'n Rides, Riverhead and other townships etc. .... I'm still working on the rail :-) - Yes and dedicated bus lanes added to the motorway (further away). Fixing the traffic between Kumeu and the motorway is so important to get sooner rather than later.
Want to know more: Pick up new bus timetables from libraries, Council service centres or go online (from 1 June). Also there's an information day at the Kumeu Library on Sat 27 May.
Dear Auckland Transport and NZTA: We still have a traffic problem on the route the bus will have to use along SH16, even with people catching the new buses (which we do gratefully thank you for :-) ).
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
We want your feedback on Easter Sunday trading in Auckland

Auckland Council wants to know what people that live and work in the Auckland region think about changing shop trading rules to allow more businesses to open on Easter Sunday. 

A recent law change means Auckland Council can decide whether to allow more shops to open on Easter Sunday. 

The council's Governing Body has decided to ask Aucklanders whether they want the council to leave things as they are or create a policy to allow more shops to open. 

Currently, only some shops, like service stations, dairies, pharmacies and food outlets, are allowed to open on Easter Sunday. Supermarkets and general retailers must remain closed. 

Visit shapeauckland.co.nz to have your say. Feedback closes at 4pm on Sunday 11 June.
link_name: About

We're honoured to have the Auckland Street Choir perform for us at Central Library next Saturday as part of our Matariki celebrations. They will be performing a 30 minute set of waiata MéÅori and we would love to invite all of our wider whéÅnau community to witness this special event!

The Auckland Street Choir is a group of singers from all walks of life. Once a week they meet to sing an eclectic mix of pop, soul, blues, R&B and folk and they aim to be inclusive and accessible in every way.

Our lucky winners are: Heather Dawson, Phillipa Wallace, and Nancy Elzeenar! Please contact us via Facebook message or at librariessocialmedia@aucklandcouncil.govt.nz with your Auckland postal address, and we will get your prizes out ASAP!

Cars 3 is in New Zealand cinemas now!

Blindsided by a new generation of blazing-fast racers, the legendary Lightning McQueen (voice of Owen Wilson) is suddenly pushed out of the sport he loves. To get back in the game, he will need the help of an eager young race technician, Cruz Ramirez (voice of Cristela Alonzo), with her own plan to win, plus inspiration from the late Fabulous Hudson Hornet and a few unexpected turns. Proving that #95 isn't through yet will test the heart of a champion on Piston Cup Racing's biggest stage!
link_name: DisneyÉ?ΩPixar's CARS 3 | Official HD Trailer 3 'Head To Head' | In Cinemas Now

Please contact us via Facebook message or at librariessocialmedia@aucklandcouncil.govt.nz with your Auckland postal address, and we will get your prizes out ASAP!

MY COUSIN RACHEL opens in New Zealand cinemas June 22.

Based on the classic masterpiece novel and from the director of Notting Hill, comes the spell binding mystery My Cousin Rachel, starring Academy Award winner Rachel Weisz and Sam Claflin. 
Given 5 stars by Best Magazine, and described as utterly seductive and suspenseful by Women and Home Magazine. MY COUSIN RACHEL is based on the classic mystery novel by Daphne Du Maurier.
link_name: MY COUSIN RACHEL | Trailer | In Cinemas June 22.

status_message:
This Wednesday our Heritage Talks series features Andrew Henry speaking on the book that changed Europe, Picart's Ceremonies: the first book to compare the world's religions in a way that encouraged tolerance. 

Come and have a look at these beautifully illustrated volumes and hear how Auckland Libraries has ended up with two sets of this seven-volume, 18th century work. Please note  this week's talk will be held in the Waitemata Room on Level 3.
link_name: HeritageTalks 2017

status_message:
What a cracking day to take Mayor Phil Goff on a whistle stop tour of Old Papatoetoe where Panuku Development Auckland is leading the regeneration of parts of the town, beginning with the rebuilding  of Old Papatoetoe Mall. 

Our CE Roger MacDonald and development team walked the Mayor through the future plan for the historic town centre before he was served coffee and cuisine from the Cook Islands courtesy of the oneCOOPERATIVE and oneBASKET pop-up community food truck stationed on George Street outside the town hall. 

A big thank you to everyone who helped to make the morning a great success.
link_name: Photos from Panuku Development Auckland's post

status_message: Hi there Sandringham, we are coming up to the end of the financial  year at council and  looking to do some more programmes  at our centre under our new manager Mike. If you are interested and you are a vendor at council, I would like to hear from you here by private mail on our facebook page. Look forward to some replies. Thanks Sandringham!   :-)

The Sandringham Playgroup and Baitul Ilm Muslim Playgroup are both based at our Sandringham Community Centre as well as the Brasileirinho NZ Playgroup from Brazil. These three playgroups contribute to the liveliness of the playground and they all have dedicated and committed responsible parents who really care for our children.Come along and join them anytime. You are all welcome to drop by,say hi and to see how they are run. Thanks Albert Eden Local Board for supporting our diverse and local playgroup communities  :-)

status_message:
Auckland Regional Public Health Service have confirmed a new case of measles.

Watch for symptoms if you've been to these public places between 7 - 12 May:

- Westfield Mall Albany Sunday 7 May, 5.20pm to 6pm   

- Hobsonville Countdown Tuesday 9 May, around 5.30pm  

- Ferry from Auckland City to Hobsonville Point  Monday 8 May, 6.15pm sailing Wednesday 10 May, 5.15pm sailing  

- Ferry from Hobsonville Point to Auckland City Wednesday 10 May, 8am sailing  

- Auckland domestic check-in and airport departure lounge Friday 12 May, 3pm - 5.30pm
link_name: New measles case confirmed

status_message:
Today our boss, David Warburton, told us he is leaving at the end of the year. 

Thanks, David,  for creating such a positive work culture, and leading the delivery of some outstanding results for Auckland.

"Hi everyone

As many of you are aware, my term as Chief Executive of Auckland Transport is coming to an end. The Board will begin a recruitment process shortly and I wanted to ensure everyone had the same message from me.

My contract ends 31 December 2017. The Board will appoint a new CE in the next few months and I expect there will be a familiarisation period before my departure. We have no clarity on the exact timing of those events at this stage, but will keep you informed as things progress.

There will be ample opportunity to both reflect and project before the end of the year. At this stage, suffice to say, after spending seven enjoyable years in the role, I think AT is in good heart, has a strong Executive Team and the business is delivering outstanding results. We have a clear "Vision", a well-defined "Mission" and an effective set of "Values". Together these give AT a great culture and place to work. Moving on at this time allows the business to transition leadership with confidence and stability.

For me, the change will allow a little more free time and an opportunity to develop/return to other interests/challenges.

In the meantime, there is a lot on and high expectations of us to continue delivering transport solutions for Auckland. Let's stay focused to ensure we meet our daily challenges with a positive attitude."
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A Labour intern says accusations of poor treatment and sub-standard living conditions at an Auckland marae don't reflect the view of the majority of interns.
"The allegations of it being a sweat shop or slave labour are completely untrue. I had a really positive experience."
link_name: Labour intern speaks out, denies accusations of poor treatment

status_message:
About 90 international interns have been staying at an Auckland marae as they volunteer for the Labour party.  But it's not what they expected when they signed up to the deal. 
Some say the dorms are cramped, doors are hanging off their hinges and the showers? Unusable. And they want to go home.
link_name: Labour accused of hypocrisy over interns' living conditions

status_message: It's one of Auckland's busiest entertainment hubs, but Sky World on Queen Street has had inadequate fire safety systems for 18 months. Despite this, the council has allowed it to stay open - business as usual.
link_name: Auckland building given WOF despite fire safety risks

status_message: Council documents state it "is likely" someone would die or be injured if a fire broke out in this central Auckland building, and the Fire Service says it's so unsafe, it wouldn't send firefighters in to rescue anyone.
link_name: Building allowed to stay open despite 'likely' death in event ...

status_message: What do your children eat at daycare? An Auckland teacher says some early childhood centres are serving mouldy bread, ignoring halal rules, and providing cake three times a day.
link_name: Mouldy food served at early childhood centres, teacher says | Checkpoint | RNZ

status_message: Loved ones were waiting in Auckland today as sailors on board the Royal New Zealand Navy's Endeavour returned home after four months at sea. After 30 years in service, the Navy's only tanker is being decommissioned.

status_message: A dairy worker was put in hospital last night after four masked men with machetes stormed into the store in Mangere. Auckland dairy owners say such attacks are now happening daily - and they're considering a mass hunger strike to bring attention to their concerns.

status_message:
This morning's council results show a Green ray of hope amongst some otherwise pretty bleak results. While the Labour vote is declining and the Tories are growing, last night the Green Party had positive results throughout England and Wales - like gaining our first Green councillor in the Isle of Wight. 

In a month's time, voters once again go to the polls and our future is at stake. Now more than ever, we need as many members talking to voters about the benefits of more Green MPs. Green MPs that stand up for our environment. Green MPs that stand up for public services. Green MPs that stand up for young people. 

This weekend, and every weekend until the general election, you can join us as we campaign for more green MPs. From Brighton to Bath, Isle of Wight to Sheffield and of course in Bristol, local green parties need your help. Help us stand up for our future. And win.

status_message: After a petition was taken to Parliament in 2015 calling for an overhaul of New Zealand's euthanasia laws, more than 21,000 written submissions were received. And the vast majority were in opposition to legalisation, anti-euthanasia group The Care Alliance determined through a lengthy analysis that was released today. But the results starkly contrast an Auckland University study earlier this year. Read more: https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/majority-submissions-euthanasia-against-its-legalisation

status_message:
Thank you to everyone who attended our Have Your Say events, both on-island and off.  We have heard some great ways in which we can improve the draft, and some really valid new ideas to consider including.  Every bit of feedback improves the three year plan.  
If you haven't been able to attend a meeting there are plenty of other ways to share your views:  respond to this post (include the words 'local board plan feedback'), email us directly on greatbarrierlocalboard@aucklandcouncil.govt.nz or fill out the online form at www.shapeauckland.co.nz.  This consulation closes on 30 June 2017.
link_name: Timeline Photos

For those that live part-time off Great Barrier Island,  this might be an easier event to get to.  It is a great opportunity to come along and talk to the board about the draft local board plan, and what priorities the boad is looking at for the next three years.

Your input into the draft plan is really important so if you can't attend the meeting (or the other Have Your Say at the Claris Conference Centre, on the island, 10 June 10am) then please provide your feedback via www.shapeauckland.co.nz between 22 May and 30 June.

We look forward to hearing from you.

status_message:
Key decisions from the May 24 2017 Albert-Eden Local Board meeting

8.1 É?? Katie Hayden, Problem Gambling Foundation of New Zealand, made a public forum presentation around gambling losses for Class 4 gambling in the Albert-Eden area.

Item 9: Public forum
9.1 É?? Resident Gillian Dance made a public forum presentation around the possible replacement of a former art sculpture at the front of Mt Albert Library.
9.2 É?? Tony Laiman, Chairperson Marist Rugby League, made a public forum presentation about Marist's proposed development plans for the clubrooms and changing rooms at Murray Halberg Park.

Item 12 Albert Eden Civic Square Plan
The board advocates to have public land set aside for town centre civic squares and requests a budget of $20,000 from 2017/2018 is allocated in the work plan to undertake the Albert-Eden 'Civic Square Plan', which includes identifying public land available, identifies planned development under the Unitary Plan including resource consents already notified.

Item 13: Proposal for Albert-Eden Local Board Community Occupancy Policy
The board adopted an Albert-Eden Local Board Community Occupancy Policy that outlines the standard terms for community leases and licences to occupy council sites in the local board area.

Item 14:  grant applications for Quick Response round three
The board approved a number of funding grants.

Item 15: Auckland Transport Report
The board requested Auckland Transport conducts traffic flow monitoring at locations at Waterview, Point Chevalier and Western Springs before and after the Waterview Tunnel opens.

Item 16: Te Auaunga (Oakley Creek) tohu
The board adopted the use of the tohu design feature to be used with the Auckland Council brand in any future place-making, and way-finding projects along Te Auaunga (Oakley Creek). Whau and the PuketéÅpapa Local Board also approved the design of the tohu.

Item 17: Easter Sunday trading
The board recommends the Governing Body retains the current arrangement, so only shops that can currently open for trade on Easter Sunday continue to do so.

The full agenda is available on Auckland Council's website and minutes will be added once confirmed.

Next business meeting of the Albert-Eden Local Board:
Wednesday 28 June at 4pm
Albert-Eden Local Board office, 135 Dominion Road, Mt Eden.
link_name: Agendas and Minutes

status_message:
Decision digest | Henderson-Massey Local Board

Local grants, community leases and work programmes approved

This meeting was livestreamed. If you didn't see it, you can watch it on this Facebook page.

From board meeting of Tuesday 20 June, 4.00pm
Council Chamber, Henderson Civic Centre
6 Henderson Valley Road, Henderson 

Items 1 É?? 12 were administrative 

Item 13: Auckland Transport Update É?? June 2017 to the Henderson-Massey Local Board
The board received the Auckland Transport update June 2017, and requested Auckland Transport erect parking signs in the Ranui Station Road cul-de-sac adjacent to Ranui School.

Item 14: Henderson-Massey Local Grants, Round Two and Quick Response, Round Three 2016/2017 grant applications
The board funded a number of grant applications.

Item 15: New Road Name Approval for the residential subdivision by Boundary Consultants at 27 Colwill Road, Massey
The board approved the proposed road name for the private way constructed within the subdivision being undertaken by Boundary Consultants at 27 Colwill Road, Massey as Mahinga Place.

Item 16: New community lease to The Order of St John Northern Region Trust Board, Lloyd Morgan Lions Club Park, 243 Edmonton Road, Te Atatu South
The board granted a new community lease to The Order of St John Northern Region Trust Board subject to certain terms and conditions.

Item 17: New community lease to Te Akoranga Playcentre Association Incorporated, Glen Norman Reserve, 93 Rathgar Road, Henderson
The board granted a new community lease to Te Akoranga Playcentre Association Incorporated subject to certain terms and conditions.

Item 18: Funding agreement for EcoMatters Environment Trust É?? Henderson-Massey
The board approved moving to a three-year funding agreement with EcoMatters Environment Trust for the years 2017-2020, terminating on 30 June 2020, for environmental initiatives to be agreed as part of annual local environment programmes.

Item 19: Henderson-Massey Local Board Libraries Work Programme 2017/2018
The board approved the 2017/2018 Libraries work programme and endorsed a change in Te Atatu Peninsula Library opening hours effective 1 August 2017.

Item 20: Parks, sport and recreation draft annual work programme financial year 2017/2018
The board approved the Henderson-Massey Parks, Sport and Recreation draft Annual work programme 2017/2018.

Item 21: Henderson-Massey 2017/2018 Community Facilities Work Programme
The board approved the Henderson-Massey Local Board 2017/2018 Community Facilities Work Programme.

Item 22: Henderson-Massey 2017/18 Local Economic Development Programme
The board approved the 2017/2018  local economic development programme.

Item 23: Henderson-Massey Local Board 2017/2018 Local environment and development work programme
The board approved the allocation of $152,000 for environment projects to be delivered by the Infrastructure and Environmental Services directorate in 2017/2018.

Item 24: Project 17: Auckland Council Maintenance Contracts
The board agreed local measures covering priorities for year one (2017/2018) of the new maintenance contracts. It noted the following sites require attention over and above standard maintenance service specifications: West Wave, Tui Glen playground, Catherine Plaza, Henderson Central Japanese Gardens.

Item 25: Local Board recommendations on Easter Sunday trading
The board strongly supports the option of retaining the status quo, so that only shops that can currently open for trade on Easter Sunday can continue to do so, and considers that it should be a central government rather than a local government responsibility to regulate Easter Sunday trading.

Item 26: Auckland Plan refresh 2018: early feedback to inform draft plan
The board delegated the coordination of feedback to the chairperson and deputy chairperson.

Items 27 - 29 were administrative 

The full agenda is available on Auckland Council's website (http://infocouncil.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/) and minutes will be added once confirmed.

Next business meeting of the Henderson-Massey Local Board:
Tuesday 18 July 2017, 4.00pm
Council Chamber, Henderson Civic Centre
6 Henderson Valley Road, Henderson
link_name: Agendas and Minutes

status_message:
Decision digest: Board agrees funding for youth leadership programme

This meeting was livestreamed. If you didn't see, you can watch it via the post below. 

From board meeting of Tuesday 16 May 2017, 4.00pm
Council Chamber, Henderson Civic Centre, 6 Henderson Valley Road

Items 1 É?? 13 were administrative.

Item 14: Henderson-Massey Local Board ACE work programme 2017/2018
The board approved the 2017/2018 Arts, Community and Events work programme.
They also agreed to enter a three-year funding agreement with West Auckland Pasifika Forum (WAPF) for the delivery of the Tula'i Youth Leadership programme. The board notes that it has been successfully run and supported by Waitakere Ranges, Henderson-Massey and Whau local boards over the past three years and has operated under an annual agreement. The programme delivers quality outcomes and the Henderson-Massey Local Board seeks to recognise this success through entering into a longer-term funding agreement so that WAPF can plan the programme.

Item 15: Information Report on the Proposed Henderson Lincoln Central Park Business Improvement District (BID) Establishment
The board received the report and acknowledged the passion and hard work of the team that worked on the BID establishment project.

Items 16 and 17: The board approved new road names.

Items 18 É?? 22 were administrative. 

The full agenda is available on Auckland Council's website (http://infocouncil.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/) and minutes will be added once confirmed.

Next business meeting of the Henderson-Massey Local Board:
Tuesday 20 June 2017 at 4pm
Council Chamber, Henderson Civic Centre, 6 Henderson Valley Road
link_name: Agendas and Minutes

status_message:
Decision digest: Harbourview-Orangihina Master Plan to begin

This meeting was livestreamed. If you didn't see, you can watch it below. 

From board meeting of Tuesday 2 May 2017, 9.30am
Council Chamber, Henderson Civic Centre, 6 Henderson Valley Road

Items 1 É?? 11 were administrative.

Item 12: New Road Name Approval for the residential subdivision by Airey Consultants Limited at 21 Hamurana Place, Te Atatu Peninsula
The board approved the proposed road name for the new road constructed within the subdivision being undertaken by Airey Consultants Limited at 21 Hamurana Place, Te Atatu Peninsula as: Arorangi Rise.

Item 13: Harbourview-Orangihina Master Plan
The board endorsed the allocation and use of up to $120,000 of funds collected by the legacy Waitakere City Council through a uniform annual charge initiated in 2001, to fund the development of a master plan for Harbourview-Orangihina Park.

Item 14: Annual Budget 2017/2018
The board endorsed its budget and advocacy points for governing body consideration for the Annual Budget 2017/2018. 

Items 15 É?? 17 were administrative. 

The full agenda is available on Auckland Council's website (http://infocouncil.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/) and minutes will be added once confirmed.

status_message: East Auckland local legend Gair McRae has received a Queen's Service Medal for her services to theatre and youth over half a century. Her love of drama started as a child when she used to direct plays in a friend's garage. As she grew up in the rural Waikato town of Huntly during the 1940s and '50s, she became a strong advocate for introducing drama into the school curriculum. https://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/stage-and-theatre/94066572/fifty-years-of-dedication-to-childrens-theatre-nationally-recognised
link_name: Fifty years of dedication to children's theatre nationally recognised

status_message: Bonnie and Clyde will be taking over the stage with a bit of song and dance, at Howick's Harlequin Musical Theatre for the next 10 days. The classic real-life story turned movie has been made into a musical by director Daniel Chasemore and stars East Auckland actress Nicolette Nes and actor Keith Marr. https://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/eastern-courier/94067436/bonnie-and-clyde-hit-howick-musical-stage
link_name: Bonnie and Clyde hit Howick musical stage

status_message: Beachlands resident Adrian du Plessis hopes his beautiful finches will do well at the Auckland Metro Bird Club's 108th annual bird show in July. In a gym-turned-breeding room at his house there are 120 finches, of 16 different varieties, living in 40 hand-made cages. Plessis plans to take 20 of these birds to the show. https://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/eastern-courier/93725858/bird-enthusiast-keen-to-share-knowledge
link_name: Bird enthusiast keen to share knowledge

status_message: The Howick Local Board has approved $30,000 to fund a "strategic operational review" of UXBRIDGE Arts & Culture to assist with future planning. https://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/eastern-courier/94032935/future-looks-brighter-for-howick-arts-centre
link_name: Future looks brighter for Howick arts centre

status_message: A man pretended to be an immigration officer and demanded nearly $100,000 from a couple, police say. The 29-year-old, from Burswood in east Auckland, appeared in the Auckland District Court on Friday afternoon. He was charged with obtaining by deception. https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/crime/94032464/man-accused-of-impersonating-immigration-officer-conning-couple-out-of-100k

status_message: Chris Griffiths, of Mellons Bay, was one of the country's 29 top students to be awarded a Freemasons Postgraduate Scholarship at Parliament's Legislative Council Chamber last month. Constable Merv Hotter is imploring motorists to obey the road safety guidelines around East Auckland schools.

"In the seven-day period, 307 vehicles stopped on the yellow lines to allow their children to exit the vehicle. Other offences of note were U-turns outside of the school where 31 vehicles executed this. A further 76 vehicles ignored the no right turn sign and 50 parked in the clear way."

status_message: Hear what Nicola Jones from Mahurangi Community Sport & Recreation has to say about a multisports facility at Warkworth. Give feedback at www.shapeauckland.co.nz or post a comment below, using the phrase 'local board plan feedback'.

Last Local Board Plan drop in at Warkworth this Saturday.  Tell us your views on investigating a targeted transport rate, funding a multisports facility at Warkworth Showgrounds, trialling buses between Warkworth and Silverdale and assisting with revitalising the Mahurangi riverfront.  Come talk to your local board members about these and other proposals in the plan.
link_name: Draft Local Board Plan - Warkworth

status_message: Did you know there are over 200 local parks in Rodney?  We want our parks and sports facilities near where we live or easy to get to if a bit further away.  We also want new or expanding areas to have places close by like a new recreation area at Dairy Flat. Give us your feedback and include the phrase 'Local Board Plan feedback' or private message us.

Next Monday is the local board plan drop in session at Dairy Flat.  Tell us your views on developing the open space at Green Road which is designated as park land and sports grounds. We're also looking at planning and developing walkways, cycleways and bridle paths in Coatesville, Dairy Flat and Wainui areas.  Drop in and talk to your local board members about this and other proposals in the plan.  #LocalBoardPlan
link_name: Draft Local Board Plan - Dairy Flat

status_message: Our next session is at Helensville so drop in this Saturday and talk to your local board members about the plan. #LocalBoardPlan.
link_name: Draft Local Board Plan - Helensville

status_message: We can get around easily and safely. Your local board wants to make better transport infrastructure and public transport a reality.  Advocating for buses, rail, park 'n ride facilities, making roads safer and key transport road projects. What about a proposal to investigate a targeted rate for transport projects? status_message: Next Tuesday is the local board plan drop in session at Wellsford. status_message: This Wednesday is the first local board plan drop-in session at Riverhead. Tell us your views on our proposals for tackling some of the tough issues facing our area. link_name: Help shape the future of your local area

status_message:
We want your feedback on Easter Sunday trading in Auckland

Auckland Council wants to know what people that live and work in the Auckland region think about changing shop trading rules to allow more businesses to open on Easter Sunday. 

A recent law change means Auckland Council can decide whether to allow more shops to open on Easter Sunday. 

The council's Governing Body has decided to ask Aucklanders whether they want the council to leave things as they are or create a policy to allow more shops to open. 

Currently, only some shops, like service stations, dairies, pharmacies and food outlets, are allowed to open on Easter Sunday. Supermarkets and general retailers must remain closed. 

Visit shapeauckland.co.nz to have your say. Feedback closes at 4pm on Sunday 11 June.
link_name: About

status_message:
Many of the great things happening in your community are a result of your ideas and input, so we encourage you to have your say!! 

Every three years each local board develops a Local Board Plan, which helps to guide decisions on local activities and projects.

Plans reflect your community's priorities and preferences; they guide the regional strategies and plans of Auckland Council, and influence how we work with others for the benefit of our communities.

Devonport-Takapuna Local Board will be asking for your feedback about plans for your local community from Monday 22 May to  Friday 30 June, 2017

By sharing your feedback you'll be involved in:

- Helping shape the future of your local area
- Ensuring Local Board Plans reflect your community's preferences
helping us understand what you value most, so we prioritize what we deliver.

You can share your feedback on Shape Auckland or keep an eye out for details in your letterbox. http://www.shapeauckland.co.nz/  

Full draft plans will also be available at libraries, service centres and local board offices.

Devonport-Takapuna Local Board have also planned drop in sessions and we invite you to come and speak to us face to face: 

Thursday 25 May 2017 
11am-1pm
Sunnynook Community Centre, 148 Sycamore Dr, Sunnynook

Saturday 10 June 2017
8am-11am
Allen Hill Stadium, 25A Lake Road, Devonport

Sunday 18 June 2017
8am-1pm
Takapuna Sunday Market, 17 Anzac St, Takapuna.

We're developing our Local Board Plan 2017 and want to know what you think about some of the projects and outcomes we propose focusing on over the next three years.

These include supporting community-led initiatives, continued improvements to the town centre and creating safe and accessible transport services and facilities.

we will be at the Matariki Kite Day, where you can stop by our drop-in session with local board members.

status_message:
We're developing our Local Board Plan 2017 and want to know what you think about some of the projects and outcomes we propose focusing on over the next three years. 

These include ensuring our environment is well cared for, growth is dealt with effectively, our local economy thrives and transport systems are improved.

We also want to know if you think we should investigate
introducing a local targeted rate to help pay for new initiatives and facilities not planned for.

Come on down to the Pukekohe Library - and meet our Local Board members and staff - have a chat and give your feedback on the draft plan.
Just go online to shapeauckland.co.nz to read the draft
Franklin Local Board Plan and to make a submission.
Feedback accepted from 22 May to 30 June.
link_name: Local Board Plan - Pukekohe Library

status_message:
And speak of the devil in relation to the Third Main and Wiri Inland Port today.

Also: 
Wiri Inland Port going South and would the Third Main still stand consequently?
For now it would not make sense for Port of Auckland to shift their facility to Drury even though if they did it could mean the Manukau South Link would be built. Even if Metro Port went to Drury the Wiri facility would act as an intermediary hub supporting the Wiri industrial complex as well as Manukau. Given Wiri still has room to support more industry (and not under thread of a decamp) the Inland Port still has many years of growth in it. The Wiri Inland Port has also just gone major expansion to its facilities and is ramping up its shuttles between itself and Port of Auckland's wharves so even with possible duplication with Metro Port Wiri will be with us for a while to come. But it does lead to an interesting dynamic of whether the Third Main would still be needed?

quote context: http://pllqt.it/SxgSCQ
link_name: Port opens additions at Wiri depot

In the seven years I have dealt with Auckland Council and its CCOs it is a mixed bag

Panuku are a very good to deal with and never had issues with them apart from comms some days being a tad slow. 

Auckland Transport? Since 2013 they are the worst when it comes to consultation exercises. Box ticking for the sake of box ticking. 

Planning Department? They be right behind AT and last night's example I saw where a young person engaging Council for the first time was chased away probably never to return (so much for the young engaging)

LIVING WAGE NOW POLICY OF AUCKLAND COUNCIL
VOTE PASSES 17-3-1

Rail could have been developed further: there was a scheme in 1950 to build light rail to the North Shore crossing the harbour at its narrowest point between Judges Bay and Devonport. Even in 1969, 22 out of 26 suburban local authorities surrounding Auckland City also supported suburban rail electrification, but the proposal would still perish in a Wellington committee. "Robbie's Rail", the rapid rail scheme proposed in the 1960s and 1970s by Auckland City mayor Dove-Myer Robinson, was scuppered partly because national-level politicians didn't seem to believe it was necessary, and cancelled the scheme.

status_message:
Mt Roskill, Papakura, New Lynn and Glen Innes will be the biggest beneficiaries of a major Government-run building programme announced this week.
These suburbs are set to get hundreds of new houses, many sold at affordable rates, by 2020.
And in an apparent first, non-resident buyers will be blocked from buying properties in some of the affordably-priced developments.
Meanwhile, South Auckland suburbs will see a lift in state houses, with plans to build more than 200 more Housing New Zealand properties in Mangere and Manurewa.
Figures provided to the Herald show the Government plans to complete construction of 9000 houses in the first three years of its 10-year programme.

status_message:
Auckland's city centre population to reach 2032 estimate 15 years early 

In 2012, Auckland's City Centre Masterplan laid out a 20-year vision for the transformation of the city centre and predicted that the 2012 population of 27,000 would reach 45,000 by 2032.
That figure is now expected to be reached this year É?? 15 years ahead of the prediction. It is now forecast to grow by a further 30,000 residents over the next 10 years, which is the equivalent of half of the population of Rotorua relocating to the area within Auckland's inner motorway.
Renaissance of inner-urban living
Councillor Chris Darby, Chair of Auckland Council's Planning Committee, says we're witnessing the rapid renaissance of inner-urban living in the city centre.

quote context: http://pllqt.it/ecOPox
link_name: Pullquote: City centre population set to exceed 2032 estimate this year | OurAuckland

It goes both ways. Yes Council and Auckland Transport need to do better but residents also need to do their part as well.

See something wrong then call, email or fill in a feedback form to Auckland Council or Auckland Transport and GET THE JOB NUMBER. If nothing in ten days then ring back with the job number.

If the problem is prevalent cc your Local Board in as well and hold their feet to the fire. 

Some parks in Auckland have been abandonned by the local council according to residents.
Casey Trent moved to Weymouth from the high-income suburb of Ponsonby two months ago - and noticed a huge difference in the state of her local park. 
"Initially I felt sad for everyone out here. It's like a stereotype - oh you live in South Auckland, you're not worth what people in Herne Bay are worth," she says.
"Is there not a budget for the whole of Auckland and not just per suburb?"
Auckland Council says there is.
"We would treat any situation where there is glass, graffiti, rubbish - the same across all our parks," Auckland Council's Agnes McCormack says.
Three former council contractors told Newshub higher income suburbs complain more to the council call centre. And that means they get more attention.  
The council admits it does rely on complaints.

quote context: http://pllqt.it/NqJ1K3
link_name: Pullquote: Lack of park maintenance forcing residents to go elsewhere | Newshub

status_message:
If you're expecting the long-awaited new Waterview Connection to ease Auckland's rush-hour traffic, prepare to be disappointed.
NZTA Auckland highway manager Brett Gliddon told The AM Show on Friday the $1.4 billion tunnel will twice a day likely suffer the same gridlock as the rest of the city.
"We've never said it would fix peak congestion in the city," said Mr Gliddon. "There's still going to be a morning peak and an afternoon peak, and the tunnel will be a part of that."
Since initial forecasting was done about a decade ago, more than 100,000 people have moved into the city.

This is Lan Pham ECan Councillor. She's a fresh water ecologist, and ran a campaign for Regional Council last year whilst stationed on Raoul Island in the Kermadecs - using social media and video. On a platform of environmental responsibility and social justice, she drummed up 55,000 votes and was elected.

Stoked to talk democracy (local and national), Christchurch issues, water, and Aotearoa's values with one of my heroes this morn. Here we are looking to the metaphorical future (it's bright).

status_message:
A thousand lucky people biked through the Waterview Tunnel on the morning of Friday 23 June 2017. Were you one of them? 

And did you spot Bike Auckland's hot pink ride marshals, keeping the ride flowing, fixing flats, and encouraging riders up that long homeward slope? 

Thanks to the NZ Transport Agency - Auckland & Northland for organizing the rides today and on Sunday, and to ScottieT Strategy and Content for the high-quality photos.

If you missed the chance to bike the tunnel,  the Waterview Shared Path on the surface will open in July/August, linking Pt Chev, Waterview, New Windsor, Mt Albert and beyond. More fun rides to come, on fresh surfaces made just for us!
link_name: Ride the Waterview Tunnel Event 2017

status_message:
A whole bunch of photos of a whole bunch of people at today's once-in-a-lifetime Ride the Waterview Tunnel event!

It's one of the most popular places to park your bike on the peninsula.... and big changes are afoot. We've got the scoop.

Naturally we have some thoughts about the plans É?? and would love to hear yours, too. Be quick to be heard, so we can all help give Auckland Transport a steer for better bike parking at Devonport Ferry Terminal!

status_message:
Once again, Tamaki Drive has made the official top ten list of New Zealanders' favourite places to ride. So why shortchange the busiest and one of the most popular bike routes in the country, with anything less than a quality approach? 

Worse: why is AT pursuing an option that will escalate conflict between bikes and cars on the road, and will literally undo 6 years of teamwork on creating harmonious relationships on Tamaki Drive and around Auckland? 

Feedback is open until Sunday 18 June. Be a good bunch É?? please spread the word to support the Bike Auckland Quality Option. Tamaki Drive is just too important not to get right!
link_name: Tamaki Drive deserves better - the Bike AKL Quality Option! - Bike Auckland

A fabulous read by Peter Calder, on the bike scene in Auckland and the way e-bikes are transforming the possibilities of how we get around the city.

status_message:
The central city bike theft epidemic continues, with break-ins and thefts of chained-up bikes. Felipe's story is eye-opening.  We hope he's reported it to Auckland City District Police, who are working hard to crack the situation. 

Bike Auckland has been collaborating with the police and AT to raise public awareness of the rash of bike thefts. What we know is, bike thieves are fast and determined and travel with cutting equipment.

So, slow them down by using the strongest lock you can buy (avoid cheap cable locks like the plague!) and always locking the bike through its frame - with two locks, even. And record your bike's serial number now É?? so that IF the worst happens and it's subsequently recovered by police, you can be quickly reunited with your ride.
link_name: Felipe

status_message:
We all want to transform our city for the better, and sooner... but what's the secret to getting stuff done?  

Join us next Tuesday 6 June for an info-rich and convivial evening with very special guest Jeff Tumlin É?? plus engaging speakers from Auckland's top three urbanist advocacy groups.

Brought to you by Bike Auckland, Generation Zero & Greater Auckland –??˝–?è?ã˜èÉ?Øã˜è–???–?æ?–??Ω–??ü
link_name: An Insider's Guide to Changing Your City

status_message:
Urban advocacy groups are playing a key role in transforming Auckland É?? so how can we get even smarter about getting stuff done?

Join us for an inspiring and convivial evening with sustainable transportation legend Jeffrey Tumlin.  In his 2015 Auckland Conversation, Jeff shared a vision of how to balance place and movement, to reclaim streets for people. Now he's back with the scoop on how we can be more effective as advocates and citizens for happy cities. 

Fresh from creating a brand new and well-balanced Dept of Transportation in car-centric Oakland California, Jeff will share a wealth of experience from cities he's worked with: Seattle, Vancouver, Moscow and Abu Dhabi, among others.

Generation Zero, Greater Auckland and Bike Auckland will unveil our current initiatives for Auckland É?? and then we'll crack into a lively shared discussion with Jeff. Bring us your best questions!

É?Ω What's the most important conversation about cities right now?
É?Ω How do we get our stories into that conversation?
É?Ω How can we make sure our values are reflected in the way our city is built and run?
É?Ω Will we see a 21st C Auckland in the 21st C? 
É?Ω Do we have to keep talking about parking spaces?

Cash bar and nibbles before, during, and after the discussion. Tickets are limited, and may be standing room only. RSVP via the Eventbrite link to guarantee your spot!
link_name: An Insider's Guide to Changing Your City

A new cycleway is up for consultation: this one will plug the gap between the busy Quay St Cycleway and the GI to Tamaki Drive shared path currently snaking its way towards town. 

The bad news: we can't support Auckland Transport's proposed design, as we believe it will endanger many existing bike travellers along what is NZ's busiest cycling route. –??Å The good news: we have an Interim Option that will work for now. –???

BREAKING: in even better news, we're working on a Quality Option, to bring you early next week. –??? You may wish to hold off on submitting until you've seen it... but please, carry on with the discussion as we value all your excellent perspectives!
link_name: Why Bike AKL can't support the design for the Tamaki Drive Cycle Route - Bike Auckland

status_message:
"It gives many more people chances to get around the city by bike, without having to resort to have a car just for that very last leg. When they come in by train they can hop on a public bike and it just makes the whole of the city so much more accessible." 

That's Bike Auckland chair Barb Cuthbert talking to RNZ about bikeshare É?? including the perennial helmet question which makes public bike hire harder than needs to be the case. Long story short: the safer the infrastructure, the lower the need for helmet protection.

status_message:
Get active your way this winter with Auckland Council Pools and Leisure's free mobile gyms.

For the next six weeks, there will be free group exercise sessions led by fitness coaches at Moana-Nui-a-Kiwa Leisure Centre, Manurewa Leisure Centre on Frances Street and Howick Leisure Centre.

Each site will be running identical weekly sessions, with a different workout each week.

There will be a mix of kettlebells, slam balls and power bags, which will get your heart rate up and muscles moving throughout the cold winter months.

Free winter workouts times and locations:

Moana-Nui-a-Kiwa Pool and Leisure Centre, Saturdays 3 June - 8 July 2017, 9am-9.45am 

Manurewa Leisure Centre, Frances St, Saturdays 3 June - 8 July 2017, 8am-8.45am 

Howick Leisure Centre, Pakuranga Highway, Thursdays 8 June - 13 July 2017, 5.45am-6.30am 

To find out more about how to get active your way, check out aucklandleisure.co.nz
link_name: Free winter workouts

status_message:
The Whau Local Board are developing their Local Board Plan 2017 and want to know what you think of the projects and outcomes they propose to focus on over the next three years.
These include building a new community facility in Avondale, working to protect and enhance our natural environment, encouraging local economic development and enabling local community arts activities.
Come along to this drop-in event to find out more, talk to local board members and give them feedback.
Or go to http://shapeauckland.co.nz/ to see a list of other events in your local board area, and to read the draft local board plan and provide your feedback by 30 June.
The draft plans are also available at libraries, service centres and local board offices.
link_name: Local board plan event É?? New Windsor

status_message: Everybody, this is Brian. He is a retired bee keeper who now teaches woman at Auckland Regional Corrections Facility all about his profession. Some of his students graduated today and he gave the most lovely speech, telling everyone that since retiring, his year teaching at the prison had been the best year ever because of the students he had worked with. When I asked Brian if I could tell people his story he said 'please make sure you mention the Howard League, they make it all possible.' What a gem.

status_message:
This surrealist work was painted by Man Ray in 1938 during the artist's first lengthy sojourn in France. An elongated female nude lies alongside a fish, creating what the artist described as 'a contrasting of similar and different forms at the same time'. The woman's flattened shape seems sparse next to the detail of the fish, creating two parallel yet disjunctive worlds. On display in 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate' until 16 July.
https://www.aucklandartgallery.com/bodylaidbare
#bodylaidbare

Image credit: Man Ray, 'Pisces' 1938 (installation view, Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, 2017), Tate: Presented by William N. Copley 1960 ∂∏ Man Ray Trust/ADAGP. Licensed by Viscopy, 2017. Image: ∂∏ Tate, London 2017
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Keep warm and dry this weekend with a visit to 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate'. Journeying through time, from the classical, biblical and literary subjects of the 1800s to the body politics of contemporary art, this beautiful exhibition brings together masterpieces by renowned artists including Auguste Rodin, Pierre Bonnard, Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, Louise Bourgeois, Barkley L Hendricks (pictured below, left), Sarah Lucas, Marlene Dumas and many more.
https://www.aucklandartgallery.com/bodylaidbare
#bodylaidbare

Image credit: 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate' (installation view), Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, 2017

status_message:
Pre-eminent collector and arts patron, Rob Gardiner, founded the Chartwell Trust in the early 1970s É?? a contemporary art collection which now numbers more than 1600 works in 2017. Chartwell remains committed to the exploration of creativity through the medium of contemporary art along with a determination to enable access to the collection and to contemporary art on a wider basis. Join Rob in conversation 3pm this Sunday with Curator, Contemporary Art, Natasha Conland as they discuss 'Shout Whisper Wail! The 2017 Chartwell Show'. Level 2 É?? free entry

status_message:
In 2016, New Zealand lost one of its leading camera artists, Marti Friedlander. For more than six decades Marti Friedlander's lens followed the lives of ordinary New Zealanders and helped shape an awareness of our diverse communities with an eye for the wild and spontaneous. Although she is perhaps best known for her iconic image of a herd of sheep, Friedlander also worked extensively offshore. New exhibition 'Marti Friedlander É?? Journeys' follows the artist outside Auckland, to the islands of the Pacific and beyond.

Now open, Ground level É?? free entry
http://bit.ly/2sJKwUC

Image credit: Marti Friedlander, 'Haifa 1957', 2000, Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, gift of Marti Friedlander, with assistance from the Elise Mourant Bequest, 2001

status_message:
Sir John Everett Millais was born on this day in 1829. Co-founder of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood É?? a secret society of young artists (and one writer), founded in 1848 É?? Millais was a childhood prodigy, being admitted to London's Royal Academy of Arts as their youngest ever student, aged 11. See his painting 'The Knight Errant' 1870 in 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate' until 16 July.
https://www.aucklandartgallery.com/bodylaidbare
#bodylaidbare

Image credit: 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate' (installation view), Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, 2017
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Walter Sickert was born on this day in 1860. A prominent figure in the transition from Impressionism to Modernism, he is regarded as one of the most influential figures in twentieth-century British art. The crumpled sheets and bare surroundings of his painting 'La Hollandaise' (pictured, centre) evokes the everyday realities of life in Camden É?? at the time one of London's poorer areas where Walter Sickert painted most of his nudes. The seedy feeling of the painting is reinforced by Sickert's handling. The brush marks form a surface so rough that, if you look at it closely, the image seems to fragment. See this work among the 'Private Nudes' in #bodylaidbare
https://www.aucklandartgallery.com/bodylaidbare 

Image credit: 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate' (installation view), Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, 2017
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
We've just added an artwork collection set to our website of a photo-essay of Pablo Picasso with friends and family at a bullfight in 1955, by New Zealander Brian Brake. The series was taken by Brake while visiting southern France with his friend John Feeney. On a Sunday the pair travelled the short distance to Vallauris where a bullfight was being held in honour of the artist. View the full series on our homepage: http://bit.ly/2hJyyqF      

One of the stars of 'The Body Laid Bare: Masterpieces from Tate', there are seven works by Picasso on display in the exhibition, including 'Nude Woman in a Red Armchair'. https://www.aucklandartgallery.com/bodylaidbare 
#bodylaidbare

Image credit: Brian Brake, 'The bullfight - Jacqueline, Picasso, Cocteau', 1955, Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, gifted in memory of Brian Brake, by a friend of the artist, 1989

CALL FOR ARTISTS
The Big Hoot is coming to Auckland early next year and up to 40 giant fibreglass owls will be displayed on a trail across the city, all with their own unique design. Submit your owl design before 5pm Monday 15 May, for your chance to be part of Auckland's largest public art trail. status_message:
Sylvia Sleigh was born on this day in 1916. An influential figure in New York's feminist art scene in the 1970s, she was particularly well known for her paintings of male nudes, which challenged the art historical tradition of male artists painting female subjects as objects of desire. Her artwork 'Paul Rosano Reclining' is on display in #bodylaidbare
https://www.aucklandartgallery.com/bodylaidbare

Image credit: Sylvia Sleigh, Paul Rosano Reclining 1974, Tate: Purchased with the support of the Estate of Sylvia Sleigh 2015, installation view, Auckland Art Gallery Toi o TéÅmaki, 2017

Auckland Transport's board meeting - where we usually get the monthly ridership results from - is not till late June but they've published the April results. We've become used to seeing impressive ridership growth on Auckland's PT network as the numbers for each month come in significantly higher than the same month the year before. However April this year was always going to be a tough month to see that trend continue as the calendar conspired against it. [  287 more words ]

Last week I wrote about what I described as the great Auckland turnaround story. Auckland seems to be beginning an urban renaissance, backed by a raft of fundamental policy reforms and new investments in urban infrastructure such as busways, metro rail, and cycleways. Of course, there are a number of flies in the ointment. Housing affordability is the big problem facing the city - we don't have enough homes for everyone who wants to buy or rent in Auckland, so prices have risen. [  933 more words ]

Bike share has schemes have exploded in popularity across the world in recent years as cities look to improve transport options. With the government's Urban Cycleway Programme has finally started to see some real investment be put into cycling infrastructure, it's timely to ask if we should be implementing bikeshare here. On Friday, Transport Minister Simon Bridges announced that the NZTA would be working with Auckland Transport and the Christchurch City Council respectively to investigate bikeshare schemes for each city. status_message:
Last week, Auckland Transport launched consultation for the western section of the midtown cycleway as part of the Government's Urban Cycleway Programme. It will run along Victoria St from Beaumont St through to Hobson St. Along the way it will link in the Nelson St cycleway and the under-construction Franklin Rd cycle lanes. In the future, it will also connect in to plans for cycle lanes on College Hill. [  678 more words ]

http://www.greaterauckland.org.nz/2017/05/18/49874/

status_message:
The government have finally announced they'll build some more houses in Auckland. They say 34,000 will be built over a decade on government owned land but that number also includes 8,300 old houses that will be demolished and thousands more that were already announced or underway, such as at Hobsonville, Northcote and Tamaki. The Government today has announced a Crown land and building programme that will see tens of thousands of new houses built in Auckland over the next decade. [  438 more words ]

http://www.greaterauckland.org.nz/2017/05/17/government-finally-build-houses-enough/

On Friday, Auckland Transport announced consultation for a paid parking scheme in Albany. Auckland Transport (AT) is looking at a paid parking zone for the Albany town centre meaning more parking for short-term visits. The proposal includes a charge of $1.00 an hour, from 8am to 6pm, Monday to Friday, with no time limit on how long you can park. A 10-minute grace period would be allowed for pick-ups and drop offs. status_message:
Auckland Live and Auckland Town Hall Organ Trust present
Benjamin Sheen
Sunday 30 July 
Aucklant Town Hall 

Benjamin Sheen is one of the world's finest young organists.

Benjamin played Rachmaninov's second piano concerto with the orchestra while a secondary school student at Eton College. He became a Fellow of the Royal College of Organists when in his teens and is the youngest organist ever to give a solo organ recital at St Paul's Cathedral in London.

He is currently organist at St Thomas Fifth Ave in New York. In this Auckland performance he'll play popular music by Bach and Vivaldi and the magnificent first movement of Elgar's organ sonata. In the second half of the programme we'll hear Mussorgsky's famous and much loved Pictures at an Exhibition. Well known for its beautiful tunes and for the delightful images created by the composer, the music takes us through a wonderful sequence of colourful scenes like the Gnome, the Market Place and the Great Gate of Kiev.

The Auckland Town Hall Organ is lauded as the best town hall organ in the world and in the hands of master organist Benjamin Sheen this concert will be thrilling.
link_name: Benjamin Sheen

status_message:
Cock
By Mike Bartlett
20 July - 12 August
Tue & Wed, 7pm | Thu É?? Sat, 8pm | Sun, 5pm
Herald Theatre, Aotea Centre

John wants out, so he's taking a break from his high maintenance boyfriend. Liberated from Mr Co-Dependent, the last thing he's expecting is to suddenly meet the woman of his dreams. Now John's stuck in a total boy-meets-girl meets-boyfriend dilemma.

Caught in a maelstrom of possibility, guilt and indecision, John reckons there's only one way to straighten this all out.

Sometimes love is worth a good fight.
Mike Bartlett's thrilling and wickedly funny play takes on sexuality and its discontents. Bring him and her.

"The jesting and jousting is hard and fast, leading to a shattering climax." - Sydney Arts Guide

"When it's funny it's hilarious, and when it moves you, it's a theatrical gut-punch." - Herald Sun

A co-presentation with Auckland Live and Silo Theatre and directed by former Silo Theatre artistic director Shane Bosher.
link_name: Cock | 20 July - 12 August

status_message:
Live Nation and Melbourne International Comedy Festival present 
Russell Howard 
Sunday 2 July 
Auckland Town Hall 

One of the UK's most successful live comedians, Russell Howard, will return to New Zealand in 2017. Russell is coming back with a brand new live show, Round the World, and this time bringing it to Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch.

Wonderbox, Russell's previous sell-out international tour in 2014, saw him entertain 285,000 fans at 40 shows across the UK and Ireland (in London alone he played four shows at the Royal Albert Hall, two shows at the O2 Arena and one show at Wembley Arena), as well as sold-out runs in the USA, Australia and New Zealand.

Don't miss it!
link_name: Russell Howard

status_message:
Take a guided tour through the grand old lady of Auckland theatre and musicals - The Civic

Auckland Live's bespoke 45-minute tour of this iconic and legendary landmark is packed full of facts, anecdotes and fun, as well as exclusive access to areas usually reserved for the stars.

Entertaining, educational and a rare privilege, The Civic Tours will delight lovers of history and theatre, as well as fans of one of Auckland's most-loved buildings. 

For our first tours, patrons will get up close to the set of West Side Story and hear firsthand the stories behind the show.

The Civic Tours are an Auckland Live Experience.

Tickets on sale Monday 22 May, make sure you don't miss out and sign up to be in the waitlist here: https://goo.gl/ayMoGJ

For more info about the tours, visit https://goo.gl/OAbZG6
link_name: The Civic Tours

status_message:
One of New Zealand's best-known actors, Mark Hadlow, returns to Auckland as the most polarising of species É?? a middle aged man in lycra: a MAMIL.

Bryan Cook is a property developer who has accumulated a small fortune building leaky homes. He's stressed out, self-medicating and self-loathing; killing himself to increase his bank balance while decreasing his golf score.

When things fall apart, he joins a men's cycling group to relieve the stress É?? and makes a few startling discoveries in various cracks and crevices.

Poignant and achingly funny, MAMIL presents the male mid-life crisis in all its lurid glory.


Originally commissioned by Auckland Live.
link_name: MAMIL

status_message:
TICKETS ON SALE NOW!
https://www.eventfinda.co.nz/2017/project-glow-wear-runway-show/auckland/mt-albert 

Lights, camera, action. It's runway show time for the second annual Project Glow Wear reflective fashion design competition.

Come along for a spectacular showcase of finalists in the competition with winners of the 13 categories announced.

7.00pm - Doors open. 
8.00pm - The show begins.

The competition boldly goes where no other has gone before by challenging designers to create reflective clothing and accessories that marry high fashion with high visual impact. 

All entries feature retro-reflective elements that highlight the wearer as they go about their early morning or evening journeys. On display will be swatches of light-activated materials entered in the Fabric Innovation category by textile pioneers.

Designers are competing for a $10,000 prize pool ranging from a $500 Levi's voucher, an internship at Mandatory Menswear to a Wacom tablet, a Singer sewing machine, shearing scissors, cash prizes and more. The pi«˘ce de r«∏sistance is the Arrow Award where the winning entry will be manufactured by the winning designer during a two-month paid internship.

This event is brought to you by the transport teams at Auckland Transport, Greater Wellington Regional Council, Hutt City Council, Wellington City Council, Kapiti Coast District Council and Upper Hutt City Council. 

The competition is supported by Levi's∂©, Arrow Uniforms, Lux Light Festival, SingerÉ?Ω, Mandatory Menswear, the Wellington Sewing Centre, Oversew Fashion, Vespertine NYC and Massey University School of Design.

For more information about the competition visit www.projectglowwear.com

status_message:
Today is World Environment Day and we're celebrating Richard Jakob-Hoff's 50 year zoo-niversary! 

Currently manager of conservation science and research at Auckland Zoo, Richard's first zoo job was at ZSL Whipsnade Zoo in England.

"I feel truly blessed to have been able to devote my life to my childhood dream of working with animals and doing something to help their conservation. On 5th June, 1967, at just 16 years old, I got my first job as a zookeeper at Whipsnade Zoo and here I am working at Auckland Zoo 50 years later!

Zoos have changed a lot over that time and I'm proud to say that Auckland Zoo's outstanding team of people are leading the way on so many fronts, especially, in the welfare of our animals and active support for the conservation of wildlife in the wild".
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It's World Turtle Day and our vet team has recently been caring for a critically endangered hawksbill turtle that washed up on Ninety Mile Beach with an amputated flipper and plastic in its system. 

After initial treatment at the Zoo, it's now being rehabilitated by the team at Sea Life Kelly Tarlton's Aquarium Auckland and will eventually be released back to the wild.
link_name: World Turtle Day

status_message:
Over the last month, our vet team has been treating Wharetutu, a kéÅkéÅpèç from Whenua Hou (Codfish Island) who has been suffering from a serious condition called cloacitis.

After weeks of intensive care, we're happy to report she has been given a clean bill of health and flew back to the KéÅkéÅpèç Recovery team on Monday, thanks to Air New Zealand. 

Go well, Wharetutu, from all of us here at Auckland Zoo!
link_name: KéÅkéÅpèç care at Auckland Zoo

status_message:
TICKETS SOLD OUT!

World-renowned giraffe experts and co-directors of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation, Dr Julian Fennessy and Stephanie Fennessy, are coming to Auckland for the very first time to share their story and passion for sticking their necks out for this most iconic gentle giant.

The Auckland Zoo Conservation Fund has been proudly supporting the ground-breaking work of the Namibian-based Giraffe Conservation Foundation since 2012. It's the world's only NGO focused on the conservation and management of wild giraffe É?? whose numbers has plummeted by over 40 percent in the past two decades.

On Saturday 13 May (6pm - 8.30pm) at Auckland Art Gallery Auditorium*, Auckland Zoo will host a one-off public screening of the extraordinary BBC documentary 'Giraffes É?? Africa's Gentle Giants' that captures some of the Foundation's daring missions and discoveries.

The Sir David Attenborough-narrated documentary will be introduced by the Fennessy's, and there will be a Q & A session following the screening.

This not-to-be-missed event is free (koha to Auckland Zoo Conservation Fund) but tickets are limited, and registration is essential. 

Register your attendance here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/VLV66KM

* Note: The Auckland Art Gallery Auditorium is accessed via the clock tower entry at the Corner of Wellesley and Kitchener streets.
link_name: SOLD OUT - Giraffe documentary screening

status_message:
It's International Asteroid Day!
Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?
Auckland has its very own meteorite story - meteorites are what asteroids are called once they hit the ground on Earth. The smooth concave meteorite crashed through the roof and into the living room of a house in Ellerslie, around 9:30am on 12 June 2004.
Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?
You can view our meterorites in one of the display cases in the Origins Gallery at Auckland Museum, and check out our gallery of meteorites on Collections Online - http://bit.ly/2uglEn6.
Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?
Asteroid Day is a global awareness campaign where people from around the world come together to learn about asteroids, the impact hazard they may pose, and what we can do to protect our planet, families, communities, and future generations from future asteroid impacts.
Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?
Originally co-founded by Dr Brian May of Queen fame, Asteroid Day is held each year on the anniversary of the largest impact in recent history, which was the 1908 Tunguska event in Siberia.
Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?Éˇ?
To learn more about how you can help and contribute, visit https://asteroidday.org/.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
To celebrate National Volunteer Week, we caught up with Bill Gray, who is a volunteer in the Auckland Museum's Collection Care team.

Bill has this week been assisting with carefully moving an art work into the Conservation Lab for some preservation work.

"The variety of the tasks is what I really enjoy, as well as the people. It's a great team here and so friendly."

"I am very pleased to give back by volunteering and to use my engineering skills, to help the Museum."

"People might not be aware of the painstaking work that goes on behind the scenes when caring for heritage objects that are in the care of Auckland Museum.

"The conservators do an amazing job. It's a privilege to see them at work and to play a part in supporting their efforts."

To learn more about volunteering at Auckland Museum, visit www.aucklandmuseum.com/get-involved/volunteer/current-volunteer-opportunities - our next round of guide training starts on 1 August 2017.
link_name: Timeline Photos

link_name: Auckland Festival of Photography Art and Contemporary Art, People's Choice

status_message:
To celebrate National Volunteer Week, we talk to Jenny Yang, who has been volunteering here for the last four months.

"I wanted to be a volunteer here as I am majoring in History and Asian Studies at the University of Auckland, and I graduate this year. I am also new to New Zealand, so volunteering helps me integrate more into New Zealand society."

"I like talking to people who came to New Zealand a long time ago and hearing their stories."

"I really like the aspect of making my own small contribution, and I am looking to do my postgraduate studies in Museum and Cultural Collection."

To learn more about volunteering at Auckland Museum, visit www.aucklandmuseum.com/get-involved/volunteer - our next round of guide training starts on 1 August 2017.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Recognise this mural? For today's #StoriesMW theme for #MuseumWeek, we wormhole back to the 1980s when artists turbo-charged the nuclear-free movement by creating a series of bold public artworks. 

This studio shot shows artists Claudia Pond Eyley, Pat Hanly, John Eaden and Margaret Lawlor-Bartlett working on the mural piece that now sits on the corner of Karangahape and Ponsonby roads. Thanks to this grass-roots movement, New Zealand was the first Western-allied nation to pass legislation and declare itself nuclear free in 1987. 

Since then, founding member of Visual Artists Against Nuclear Disarmament and Mt Eden resident, Claudia Eyley has gone on produce a number of documentaries about the nuclear free movement, including "No Nukes Is Good Nukes!". 

To find out more about this collection item see here: http://www.aucklandmuseum.com/collections-research/collections/record/am_library-photography-92277?k=claudia%20pond%20eyley&ordinal=10

Hanly, Gil (1985). Claudia Pond Eyley, Pat Hanly, John Eaden and Margaret Lawlor-Bartlett. Visual Artists Against Nuclear Arms Murals preparation, Outreach Auckland War Memorial Museum TéÅmaki Paenga Hira. PH-2015-2-GH1126-10. ∂∏
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
What was the mystery event at Waihi Marae, Taupo on 18 April 1959?   A simple broadsheet poster written in te reo started a search for information in the Auckland Museum library. 
Geraldine Warren, Collections Manager, MéÅori Resources at Auckland Museum, delves into this further at www.aucklandmuseum.com/collections-research/collections/topics/front-page-news-a-mystery-hui

Image caption: Man, possibly Hone Taiapa master carver, wearing duffle coat & hat, holding camera, points to a carving in front of meeting house to young girl. Beattie, Bill (18/04/1959). Opening Maori Meeting House, Waihi, Taupèç. Auckland War Memorial Museum TéÅmaki Paenga Hira. PH-NEG-H601.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Last week we were delighted to host Auckland photographer, KT Ho and Brett Aghan as part of Ho's photographic project to document Chinese people reconnecting to ancestral objects. In these pictures, Brett holds the military ID tag worn by his grandfather Alfred Aghan who served as a member of the New Zealand Mounted Rifles in WW1. These tags are among other items associated with Alfred kindly donated to the Museum by the Aghan family, including regimental badges and a notebook containing a poem Alfred wrote about his horse. Currently, a number of these objects are on display in the Pou Maumahara Memorial Discovery Centre. "It is surreal looking at these objects now considering my sisters used to play with them, like our grandfather's medals. I feel like now these objects are in their proper place," says Aghan. http://bit.ly/2rDa1Z6
link_name: Photos from Auckland Museum's post

Talofa lava everyone. This is the cover of "Tala mo tamaiti Samoa", a journal which is part of the Library's Documentary Heritage collection - for further information, visit Collections Online - www.aucklandmuseum.com/collections-research/collections/record/am_library-catalogq40-38803?k=Tala.

The stories were adapted by a Samoan student, Fanaafi Ma'ia'I - read more about her in the 'Salient' from 1958 -
http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz/tm/scholarly/tei-Salient21061958-t1-body-d17.html.

A selection of publications are on display for the duration of this year's Pacific Language Weeks in the end case in the Library Reading Room.

Image caption: Cover page of Tala mo tamaiti Samoa.
