status_message: This fund was valued at $355 million just last year. It has returned an average of 9.6% since 2010 and was manged to enable an annual draw down of $23 million. ACIL said it "...provided a significant return on investment and contributes to the improved liquidity position and credit rating of Auckland Council." Now, in little over a yea,r this 'rainy day' fund inherited from legacy councils will have gone - $100 million already disappeared into the debt ether, a further $100 million due to go the same way and the final $130 million voted away this week, though this time loosely tagged to 'infrastructure' provision (but with absolutely no  information as to what specific infrastructure or where). If this is the way a valuable income producing asset can be disposed of so easily without a single word of public consultation and without any meaningful substantiation to where it's going, then watch out Auckland - what's coming next?
link_name: Auckland councillors divided over financial asset sale

status_message:
Silverdale lights a recipe for gridlock - see quotes from recent article ---A proposal to install traffic lights at the bottom of the Silverdale Hill has drawn sharp criticism from 5 of the 6 elected  representatives from the Hibiscus Coast. Both ward councilors, John Watson and Wayne Walker are opposed to another set of  lights, as are 3 of the 4 HBC local board members - Vicki Watson, Mike Williamson and Caitlin Watson.  All five say lights at this location will cause serious congestion on the Hibiscus Highway.
 Cr John Watson says that when this proposal was considered back in 2011, Auckland Transport rejected it emphatically saying it would cause major traffic hold ups back along the Whangaparaoa Peninsula and it would be dangerous - trucks would have difficulty coming to a stop safely at the bottom of the hill." 
Now Auckland Transport have said they will undertake a feasibility study to once again consider installation of the traffic lights, including the provision of warning lights, a reduction in the speed limit to 50 km and the 'realignment' of the road. 
"The cost for this would run to millions of dollars  and the result would be gridlock on an already congested road É?? it's lunacy," says Watson. "Both the local board leadership driving this proposal and AT have been told repeatedly that lights at this location will cause significant traffic problems but they will not listen." 
Cr Wayne Walker says that what makes this proposal all the more difficult to understand is that there are already plans to extend  East Coast Road across the Weiti River by Pak and Save and  into Silverdale. 
"This will address the problem of access across the Highway and is part of an accelerated transport package for Silverdale already agreed to É?? the lights aren't needed." 
The 3 Hibiscus local board members opposed to the lights are also concerned that the study is being advanced without consultation with the wider public and with no apparent regard for the impact on the thousands of commuters living on Whangaparaoa. They believe HBC motorists will be aghast at what's being proposed and will reject it categorically.

Myself and fellow Albany ward councillor did not vote for the targeted rate - see story blow.                                             Albany Ward councillors John Watson and Wayne Walker voted against the controversial 'bed tax' targeted rate which was passed 11 -8 at last week's council meeting.
They did so largely because of the effects it will have on local businesses in the Albany Ward.
"This rate is just not fair to our local motel businesses," says John Watson. "They are being charged a targeted rate for a service they don't receive."
They don't receive any actual benefit from ATEED's tourist promotions which concentrate largely on event promotions in the city.
"Why should they pay a rate for a service they don't receive any benefit from? No one could really answer this at the meeting."
The sums of money involved are significant É?? on the HBC the targeted rate amounts range from an extra $4000 to $16000 extra a year for local moteliers
This is on top of the commercial rates which they already pay which range from $13,000 to $52,000 per annum.
"Put them together and some of our moteliers will be paying from $17 K to $66 K a year in rates."
To make matter worse some of their competitors in the region will not be getting charged the targeted rate É?? the outer parts of Auckland like Rodney and Franklin are exempted from the rate as are bed and breakfasts.
Hotels on strata title will be able to apply for a rate remission as will hotels who can show they have already forward booked customers. 
Hibiscus Coast and other Albany ward moteliers operate in a very price sensitive environment É?? when people book through the likes of Trivago and Trip Adviser relatively small sums of money can make all the difference when it comes to choosing a place to stay.
"This proposal has tried to substitute a targeted rate for a visitors' levy and it simply doesn't work."
For the big city hotels the sums money involved are significant É?? some of the big hotels will be paying up to an extra $700,000 through this rate (on top of commercial rates of a similar magnitude). That will have also have implications for their businesses. 
Both John Watson and Wayne Walker agree that ratepayers shouldn't be paying for tourist promotion but say council could simply withdraw the $13.45 million of promotions until such times as a fair system can be worked out with the accommodation providers.

On 1 June Auckland Council voted to adopt the Annual Budget 2017/2018.

Important decisions in the budget include:

a general rates increase of 2.5 per cent for all ratepayers
a living wage for Auckland Council employees on low pay
funding to coordinate action on homelessness
a broader revenue base for the council via a targeted rate on commercial accommodation providers
new targeted rate mechanisms to fund infrastructure for new houses
a $200 million boost to spending on infrastructure with $2 billion in capital spending this year

There are concerns emerging over the restructuring of our libraries (i.e reducing the number of staff and changing work conditions though not the opening hours it should be noted) and the effect this is having on staff morale. I doubt whether there are more friendly and helpful people than our council library staff - they always have been from time and eternity no matter where you go right across Auckland - for children, students and the general public - and  increasingly a much wider community resource than just the issuing of books   - . It would be really good to hear what the actual staff think?
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The Rodney Times is right - this meeting was a shambles and marred by petty infighting that will have done little to engender public confidence. I thought it might be useful, however, to give a little background to the comments made by Mr Barnett in Silverdale.

Firstly, earlier this year there was another Penlink meeting hosted by the local board on behalf of the Chamber of Commerce and Mr Barnett. The two ward councilors were not invited to this meeting, nor were three of the four Hibiscus Coast local board members (that means 5 of the 6 HBC representatives were not invited). All of us knew absolutely nothing about it. 

As a result of this a complaint was sent to the Board chair at the end of March who initially denied that it was a local board hosted event despite the fact the Chamber of Commerce had stated that it was so on their website. To be honest we're more focussed on working out a financial package that makes the project fly (and with those individuals who actually have the capability to do so) but my view is that in so far as those involved with these meetings go, far from looking to involve people they've actually been doing all they can to exclude them - councillors and local board members alike.

On Friday we had the curious situation then where Mr Barnett alleged that we don't bother to attend their meetings. It's a little hard to attend meetings you don't know anything about!! When we were invited to the one last year, we did attend the event down at the marae in Silverdale despite Mr Barnett saying that we didn't (the local board chair had to correct him on that). In reality I haven't even had a conversation with Mr Barnett...ever!!  When I did email him last year to thank him for the Chamber's involvement and to offer support, he didn't reply. When I've further  asked him twice  this week for a meeting  he's refused to respond yet again - hardly the spirit of collaboration. 

I would like to know though who the board member is who is giving Mr Barnett all his information  since he is clearly not getting it from any contact with us! Maybe it's that mystery Councillor who was at the centre of the dissolution of  the dysfunctional Rodney Council back in the early 2000s when she turned on all the other HBC councillors in order to maintain her own position and in so doing provoked such bitter infighting and division that Rodney became the first council in the history of NZ to be dismissed by the Minister of Local Government and replaced by a Commissioner. Surely it's not deja vu - the same person provoking discord again?
 
Whatever the answer it certainly appears to us if there are people on the local board playing petty politics with Penlink , looking to advance their own profile while simultaneously denigrating others. That's very disappointing and ultimately counterproductive.   

The public want to see all the elected representatives working together (as was commented on at the meeting). In this respect it was also uncalled for to attack the Rodney MP Mark Mitchell who has worked hard for Penlink and especially when efforts are also now being made to progress Penlink as a road of National Significance with the government, a government in which Mr Mitchell now holds a senior position É?? hardly the way to win friends and influence people.
Finally while it's certainly nice to see the Chamber conducting surveys showing the high level of public support and a willingness to pay tolls, that's hardly a newsflash to anyone. We've all known that for the last 20 years. Unfortunately just banging the drum and making a lot of noise doesn't actually progress anything É?? we all know that from the bitter experience of the last two decades.
 
Efforts have to be far more sophisticated than that and which concentrate on alternative sources of finance, and that's what we're absolutely focused on as councillors - coming up with an actual agreement that makes Penlink happen in advance of the current timetable - for there are parties genuinely interested in constructing it if the right financial package can be agreed upon that takes into account the complexities of the council's debt profile, future tolling income, NZTA subsidies and investor contribution and return. Unfortunately there were actually investors at this meeting that we have been working with this year regarding Penlink - I shudder to think what they made of the circus on Friday. 

Still, there is the clear requirement at the moment to be fully cognizant of the rapidly changing political and financial scene in Auckland. The sheer volume of housing enabled by the Unitary Plan passed at the end of last year now raises the possibility of Penlink being progressed, in whole or in part, as a road of elevated significance. And that most certainly requires a united front and more importantly, the appropriate financial package that satisfies all the relevant parties and progresses this project significantly ahead of time. So let's work together on this, no more petty posturing, self-promotion and denigration of others - we're all from the same community after all - no one person or group can do it alone - as with most things  it has to be a team effort that utilises people's collective abilities.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It was fantastic to visit Rowandale School in Auckland today and announce that $21 million will be invested for more new classrooms in Auckland as part of Budget 2017.

This investment will see 41 new classrooms built, including 34 roll growth and seven replacement classrooms, at eight schools across Auckland.
 
The schools receiving new classrooms are:
∂˙         Beachlands School É?? 10 classrooms
∂˙         Dominion Road School É?? 4 classrooms
∂˙         Meadowbank School É?? 4 classrooms
∂˙         St Thomas School, stage 2 É?? 9 classrooms
∂˙         Bairds Mainfreight Primary School É?? 2 classrooms
∂˙         Rowandale School É?? 6 classrooms
∂˙         Te Kura Kaupapa Maori o Te Kotuku É?? 2 classrooms
∂˙         Onehunga Primary School É?? 4 classrooms
 
The 34 new roll growth classrooms will provide around 680 additional student places to help schools with growing rolls.

The additional places are part of a total 4,000 new student places being delivered through Budget 17 for the Auckland region.

This investment is part of the $240 million investment allocated for Auckland school infrastructure under Budget 2017, which provides $87 million for roll growth classrooms across the city.

Budget 17 is investing $456.5 million in education infrastructure nationally.

This takes the Government's overall commitment to extending and upgrading schools in recent years to over $5 billion.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
This morning I announced consultation on new digital technologies content for the New Zealand Curriculum and MéÅori-medium Curriculum, Te Matauranga o Aotearoa.

On a visit to Newmarket Primary School in Auckland with the Prime Minister, I introduced the draft content for Digital Technologies/Hangarau Matihiko, in the technology learning area of the national curriculum.

We live in exciting times, with digital technologies advancing at an incredible rate and playing an ever increasing role in all aspects of our lives.

The new curriculum content is about ensuring that students across all year levels have access to rich learning aimed at building their digital skills and fluency, to prepare them for this world

The new content covers two key areas, 'computational thinking' and 'designing and developing digital outcomes', and has been designed to be flexible, so it can respond to new developments and technologies as they emerge.

Through the consultation process, educators, business and industry, parents, families and whanau will all be able to help the Ministry of Education shape the final content of the curriculum.

We want everyone to have their say and help us prepare this generation of children and young people for the future. The consultation period runs until the end of August.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: A big afternoon on Waiheke Island meeting with a group of businesses, then local board representatives followed by the renaming event of the Waiheke community art gallery. We were also acknowledging the stone carving by Piritahi Marae and celebrating Matariki. The gallery is now called Te Whare Taonga O Waiheke. The gallery has been instrumental with events like Headland Sculpture on the Gulf which is known throughout parts of NZ as an outstanding event. It was lovely to recognise people like Linda Chalmers (recently recognised in the NZ honours) for their huge community contribution to the island. I was touched to receive this beautiful kete from the gallery which I plan to keep in my ministerial office in Wellington to celebrate the creativity of Waiheke.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Several hundred people in a packed room for the launch of our Auckland National Party Bluedragons. Dr Jian Yang  has lead the way with ensuring more Chinese kiwis are politically active in communities than ever before. We talked about safer communities, a stronger economy and improving our education system. It is a very different organisation in terms of office holders and membership than it was 10 years ago. The National Party membership is more diverse and representative than ever before.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
I have a new website that is easier to use and covers both my work for communities in Auckland central and as Minister of Education and Youth. You will b able to find it in the future at www.nikkikaye.co.nz. I will be publishing more of the my 30 top projects for Auckland central soon. 

A bit of an Auckland Central Projects Update. Along with my national responsibilities I continue to work on a range of local issues and projects for Auckland Central, which include:

- Construction is now well underway since the Government announced a significant funding commitment to the City Rail Link late last year. I have supported the CRL project since 2009 and have liaised with a number of individuals and groups including the Auckland Council regarding project disruption in central Auckland.  Budget 2017 included $436 million for the first stage of the City Rail Link to greatly boost the capacity of the commuter rail network in central Auckland.

- Progressed redevelopments at Bayfield School ($12 million) and Freemans Bay School ($19 million) as well as the $79 million redevelopment at Western Springs College (an important secondary school for Auckland Central residents).

- Progress on reform of the Unit Titles Act, affecting many  electorate residents of apartments. I started a campaign for change and have worked with a group of property professionals and the Minister for Building and Housing to improve the law. Proposals are currently being worked through covering improvements in dispute resolution and greater transparency of information for people living in apartments and townhouses.

- $88 million package of cycleways benefiting Auckland and Auckland Central.

-$40 million property investment for Waiheke Schools (Waiheke High School and Te Huruhi School).

-Rollout of ultra-fast broadband on Waiheke Island recently completed. This is hugely important for social and economic progress for island residents and businesses.

- Earlier this year I approached the Auckland council, Auckland Transport and the Mayor regarding greater investment and improved ferry services for Waiheke. They have confirmed they are now working on a revised ferry strategy which will cover Waiheke Island. 

-Advocated and helped deliver the opening of the Aotea Conservation Park and re-opening of the Aotea Track on Great Barrier Island. I am currently advocating for additional tourism funding for the island including giving greater national recognition to the Aotea track.

-Helped to ensure the learning hub is resourced for Great Barrier Island students. I am currently exploring the potential for tele-health services for the island.

-Improved cellphone reception for Great Barrier Island with a new cell site going live in the north of the island.

Each year my office and I continue to deal with more than 10,000 constituency queries or issues from people and organisations. These queries, my constituency clinics and feedback from door knocking have led to the development of new policies and projects that address issues at the heart of this constituency.

There are numerous other projects that I am working on both locally and nationally, so please contact me if you would like further details.
link_name: Nikki Kaye

status_message:
The Prime Minister and I had a beautiful and warm welcome at Roscommon School in Auckland today. I announced an additional $7.6 million over four years to invest in creating more curriculum resources in MéÅori language.

Students in MéÅori medium and English medium kura and schools will benefit from the new resources, which will be created to support students both learning te reo MéÅori as a subject, and studying other subjects in and through te reo.

We have around 180,000 children and young people participating in MéÅori language in education across MéÅori medium and English medium schooling settings. 

I also spoke about the $1.7 million that will fund the ongoing support provided to Boards of Trustees of MéÅori medium schools by Te Runanga Nui o NgéÅ kura kaupapa MéÅori o Aotearoa (TRN) and NgéÅ Kura éÅ-Iwi o Aotearoa (NKAI).
link_name: Budget 2017: Supporting MéÅori language and kura management

status_message:
I have just visited Stonefields School in Auckland to announce the details of the $240 million Auckland School property investment under Budget 2017.

This investment will deliver four new schools:

- $22m for a new primary school in the Pukekohe Belmont area (planned roll of 350)
- $25m for a new primary school in Orewa North West area (planned roll of 420)
- $20m for a new primary school in the Drury area (planned roll of 370)
- $24m for a new kura in Manurewa, to house Te Kura Kaupapa Maoro o Manurewa and Te Wharekura o Manurewa

The package also includes:

- $20m phased expansion for Stonefields School, which will eventually provide 450 additional places
- $22m for co-location and rebuild of Carlson and Sunnydene special education schools on a new site
- $87 million for around 170 classrooms across Auckland, both new and replacement and $9 million for five new special education satellite units. 

We have now announced all nine of the new schools that were pledged in 2014. With the package announced today, a further 4000 student places will be delivered, on top of the 17,000 already announced. This means we are on track to deliver an extra 21,000 student places in Auckland by 2021.

https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/budget-2017-240m-auckland-school-property-investment-unveiled
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Congratulations to all those involved in the project to light up the harbour bridge with the support of about 700 solar panels. 

In a world first, the energy required for the nearly 90,000 LED lights and 200 floodlights will be offset by solar and battery technology.

The LED lights will use half the energy and will last five times longer than standard lighting, and only need replacing every 10-15 years. The energy required will be offset by 700 solar panels installed near the Harbour Bridge where a large battery will store the energy. I know NZTA, council and vector have all worked together in strong partnership to make this happen.  

https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/auckland's-nightscape-be-transformed

Authorised by Nikki Kaye MP, 48C College Hill, Freemans Bay, Auckland.
link_name: The $10m light show: Auckland Harbour Bridge set to be lit up - National - NZ Herald News

status_message:
#Budget2017 increases school capacity throughout New Zealand with a $465.5m investment in school property, including $392.4 million of capital funding and $64.1 million of operating funding over four years. 
This will provide six new schools, two school expansions, the relocation of two special education schools, 11 new special education satellite unites and around 305 new classrooms nationwide. 

To break this down; Auckland will see a total of $277.6m invested into projects including four new schools, one school expansion, the relocation and rebuild of two special education schools and around 170 more classrooms at schools across the city. This Government is getting ahead of growth, delivering 21,000 extra student places in Auckland from 2014 É?? 2021. 
Outside of Auckland, we continue to focus on providing fast-growing communities with significant investments in new schools and classrooms. 
#Budget2017 also provides $146.9m for school property including two new schools, one school expansion and 130 extra classrooms around the country.

#Budget2017 also provides $31.9m for land purchases to ensure we can build new schools to meet demand. 

Overall this Government has committed more than $5 billion towards school property, significantly more than any previous Government. We have been fixing the poor state that school buildings were in when we took office by investing this in brand new schools, school expansions, new learning spaces and roll growth classrooms throughout New Zealand
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
This morning I made a special visit to Auckland Grammar School to celebrate Kate Edger, who was New Zealand's first female university graduate. In 1874, when Kate was 16, she was given permission to attend Auckland Grammar as there was no secondary schooling available for girls at the time. She was the only girl in her class. 
Kate was a trailblazer and went on to gain a Bachelor of Arts in Latin and Mathematics. 
I spoke to the Grammar assembly about how success takes courage and Kate is a fantastic example of someone who showed resilence and determination to achieve what some people may have thought was impossible. Later in life she was active in the suffrage movement and involved in causes supporting women and children. We have much to owe women like Kate, who changed society through their convictions and determination, and who made the road easier for those who follow in their footsteps. Great to have local MP and old boy David Seymour there too.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: After a long day of lots of Auckland central constituency meetings, it was great to top it off by chatting with some inspirational young people from the YMCA Raise Up group. The YMCA invests a lot into improving the lives of these young New Zealanders so it was a pleasure for me to hear a little bit about their stories and some of the events they have organised. These young people have done a great job getting hundreds of young people involved in events across Auckland –???–??ç
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
There is no one answer to increasing the number of teachers or strengthening the profession which is why we are supporting a range of new initiatives. These build on the $9 million package announced by the previous Education Minister last year that was designed to help address teacher supply pressures and build and maintain a quality teacher workforce.

Firstly in the upcoming budget we will commit $5.2 million over the next four years to expand the innovative employment-based initial teacher education (ITE) programme provided by Teach First NZ to a further 90 participants.

We're also committing $2 million of operating funding over the next two years towards further induction and mentoring for provisionally-certificated teachers in priority areas to gain full certification.

I can also confirm today that the Education Council will be going out to tender for the provision of Teacher Education Refresher courses. The tender will aim to both improve the quality of these courses while also reducing the costs which I understand may be prohibitive for some teachers wishing to get full certification.

And from the beginning of next year we will lift the moratorium on new study programmes for teacher qualifications which has been in place since 2000.

In order to raise achievement it is crucial that we continue to improve the quality of teachers. The replacement of the Teachers Council with the Education Council has been an important step towards enabling the profession to raise standards in teaching. The Government has provided financial support to get the organisation up and running.

The Council is an independent statutory body mandated to lift the status of the teaching profession. They are focused on good teaching practice and helping to raise the status and image of the teaching profession. They have recently consulted on a new professional code which covers expectations of ethical behaviour and standards of professional practice for the teaching profession. They have also signalled that they have been reviewing the qualifications required for teachers to be able to practice. These are important pieces of work and I look forward to being briefed further by the council in the coming months on this work.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: A big day in NZ politics saying goodbye at cabinet to two of my closest political mates the Hon Hekia Parata and the Hon Murray McCully. Both will be remembered for a long time to come and I have been fortunate to have worked alongside both of them in the good times and the bad. When I came back from London in 2008 to run for Parliament I met with Murray for a coffee. Most people with the exception of Murray told me it was an impossible task to win the nomination let alone the seat of Auckland central. Murray not only encouraged me to stand for the nomination but was always a phone call away when I was a newbie MP knocking on doors and meeting people in Auckland central. Murray has delivered so much particularly in the areas of high performance sport but also helping secure the top job for NZ on the UN Security Council. He is one of the longest serving ministers in our countries history. I never liked the oaky warm Chardonnay but I did love our political discussions –???As I have already said Hekia has been a superb colleague and a close friend. She is so capable and has delivered so much in education. She is in my view the best education minister we have ever had. Alongside her and her husband Sir Wira they have been so loyal and dedicated to the party for so long. Thank you again HP and MM for all your service to NZ –??çÉùœã˜è–??ç
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Recently our ecologists were out monitoring a population of Thelypteris confluens, also known as swamp fern. There are only a couple of populations of it remaining in the Auckland region. Formerly common in lowland coastal wetlands, its distribution has been severely reduced from wetland drainage and reclamation. To find out how you can help restore wetland ecosystems visit our website http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/environmentwaste/biodiversity/Pages/wetlands.aspx

Myrtle rust has reached NZ. MPI and Auckland Council are asking Aucklanders to keep their eyes peeled for this invasive fungus and to report it immediately if spotted. Do not touch the fungus or try and take samples as this will increase the risk of it spreading. Note down its location and take photos if possible.

http://ourauckland.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/articles/news/2017/05/invasive-myrtle-rust-disease-discovered-on-mainland-nz/
